The orange will accent the fragrance and intensy the rose and peppercorns notes.The lines of gin and rum are made at the Elrick estate, within the garden walls of a home veiled in mystery and tradition. Built at the height of the Scottish Enlightenment period in , the house boasts a rich history.As the restoration project continues, the team welcomes you to indulge in a drink and share their journey and will open as a venue for weddings and events later this year.houseofelrickwww.facebook houseofelrick-------------------------------------Tiree GinThe latest addition from Tiree Whisky Company , Hebridean Pink Gin is distilled and bottled on the Isle of Tiree, the outermost of the Inner Hebridean islands.Tiree is a fertile and remote island, famed for sunshine and stunning scenery, and is surrounded by the vast Atlantic Ocean. In the eighteenth century, the island was home to around fty distillers with each farm on the island operating at least one still producing whisky.This began to decline as tighter regulations from both the estate and the government were introduced. Although a large number of islanders were still making whisky illegally, this industry ceased completely in the nineteenth century.#Tiree Whisky Company Ltd was established by locals Alain Campbell and Ian Smith with the aim of reviving the spirit industry on an island with a rich heritage in the tradition.Local production of Tyree Gin began in February  and, once again, the island was home to an operational distillery - the first in  years.Hebridean Pink Gin is distilled with juniper, raspberries and sweet peels. The stunning bottle was designed by Glasgow based design agency, O Street, and the striking design certainly catches the eye.Pre-order available with delivery from thJuly.www.hebrideanpinkgin---------------------------------Pentlands Hills GinNestled deep in the western Pentland Hills, Tarbraxus Distillers is home to the award-winning Pentland Hills Gin.The company was created by Phil and Tabatha who set about delivering not just a first-class gin, but a gin thatrsquos distilled in the most sustainable fashion possible.The gin reflects the le they live in the hills first up, however, you have to meet Panza, the chocolate Labrador who is the CEO .The Companyrsquos original gin is distilled using nine botanicals, some of which are grown around the farm. Double distilled in a copper still called Amy, the gin offers a very smooth impression on first sipping.For some the taste of citrus will emerge, for others maybe a hint of aniseed or cocoa. This % abv gin is full of surprises. Served with pink grapefruit it makes a delicious GT. In a martini, the gin offers the perfect  moment.The gin is also offered at Navy Strength ndash % abv. Despite this big mouthful of alcohol, it is remarkably smooth and can be happily sipped naked! As a GT it offers hints of toffee and citrus, for the adventurous try mixing a Vesper ndash you wonrsquot be disappointed.Sustainability drives Phil and Tabatharsquos ethos. The distillery uses solar energy, water rises on the land and juniper has been planted to help the regeneration of the berry which is key to all gin distillation.Perhaps the greatest innovation is the lsquobottle for lersquo approach to the way the gin is sold. You buy your first etched bottle and it is marked with your personal number. When itrsquos time to replace the gin you post is back .Even better your gin bottle can be switched from Original to Navy gin and back as you wish. As Panza says, lsquoitrsquos a woofingly good idea!rsquoThe gin is produced in tiny qualitiessoyoursquore lucky enough to own a bottle enjoy every drop and then have it refilled by people who really care about how they create and deliver your tipple.www.pentlandhillsginor #PentlandHillsGin @PentlandHillsGin @PentlandGin-----------------------------Esker SpiritsA family-run business led by husband  we team, Steven  Lynne Duthie, Esker Spirits has evolved from a kitchen hobby, to distilling in the shed before, in April , moving to premises in the beautul Kincardine Estate on Royal Deeside, Aberdeenshire. And itrsquos here in Royal Deeside where the inspiration for Esker Spirits comes from ndash all the spirits contain the sap from silver birches which are everywhere around the distillery.Says Lynne: ldquoWe have our own distillery ndash and make, bottle, deliver and enjoy our gins. All our gins are full flavoured ndash there is no relying on mixers or garnish for flavour, itrsquos all packed into the gin.Photo: The Gin Cooperative LtdAll of Eskerrsquos gins start in the same way with classic gin botanicals and the Esker twist ndash silver birch sap from the Kincardine Estate. Distilling days start early, using traditional copper stillsto make the gin ndash the smell in the distillery when they are working is incredible.Esker Gin is the flagship ndash a classic London Dry gin, great in a gin and tonic with ice and a twist of orange zest, it is a beautully smooth gin. Esker, along with its sister gin, Esker Goldhave won IWSC Gold Medals and Great Taste stars.Photo: The Gin Cooperative LtdThe flavour profile of Esker Gin is smooth, clean and juniper led. This classic gin has its own distinctive notes with over a dozen botanicals, locally sourced silver birch sap, citrus and a hint of the floral botanicals.In addition to Esker Gold, the range also includes the Silverglas gins ndash a light, fresh London dry, and two fruit gins, Scottish Raspberry Gin and Valencian Orange Gin. The fruit gins are made with real fruit, not syrups or cordials. ldquoItrsquos a lot of work, but worth it for the end product, Lynne adds.Photo: The Gin Cooperative LtdBuilding on the brand, and tapping into the market for lighter, fruit flavoured drinks, Esker Spirits has recently lived up to its name by extending the spirits range to include two fruit vodkas .Of the future, Lynne says: ldquoWe are focusing on building our brand and making it easier for our customers to find our spirits on the shelf ndash whether they are in a shop, or in a bar. There is always some development work going on at the distillery so you never know when new products might start appearinghellip watch this space!www.eskerspiritsFacebook: @eskerspiritsInstagram: @eskerspiritsTwitter: @esker_spirits----------------------------Red Door GinRed Door Gin is carefully handcrafted at Benromach Distillery in Forres, where every drop is distilled in ldquoPeggy ndash the small copper pot behind the distilleryrsquos iconic red door.Launched in , Red Door has already won a Gold Medal at the Gin Masters with the  of expert judges commenting on the ginrsquos ldquochocolatey nose, earthy taste, woody, rooty notes and a little liquorice sweetness. Delicate enough to sip and savour neat, perfect with fresh raspberries in a classic GT or packing a punch in a classic cocktail, this is a gin that can do it all.Focusing on quality over quantity, the distillery produces two ieties ndash Red Door Highland Ginor Red Door Gin with Winter Botanicals . Both are equally delicious and itrsquos impossible to pick a favourite.For those with a real thirst for gin knowledge, be sure to put the Red Door Gin Visitor Experience on your staycation to-do list . With only eight spaces per tour, this is a chance for visitors to learn first-hand about the history of the distillery and how each batch of handcrafted ndash and award-winning ndash Highland gin is made.Housed behind the distilleryrsquos iconic red door, this one hour tour will bring the distillation process to le while introducing guests to ldquoPeggy ndash the small copper pot still where every batch of Red Door Gin is carefully handmade by the on-site team.After learning about botanicals and distillation, visitors can make their way to the Red Door Gin bar to sample the perfect Red Door GT or signature cocktail. Itrsquos on the site of Benromach Distillery, so while yoursquore there why not pop in to learn about this iconic Speyside single malt too  Itrsquos the only distillery in Speyside to offer gin and whisky visitor attractions at one site and is well worth a visit.Red Door Highland Gin and Red Door Gin with Winter Botanicals are available from www.reddoorgin our-shop for pound. cl.------------------------------Teasmith GinItrsquos been a busy year for The Teasmith Gin creators Nick and Emma Smalley. The makers of the first Scottish Gin distilled with hand-picked tea have been slowly expanding their list of stockists across Scotland and the UK. saw them collect another swathe of awards including the Spirits Business Masters Medal for their packaging and design of their flagship product The Teasmith Original. They also released Broich Single Estate ndash a limited edition gin featuring tea grown right here in Scotland.Why tea  Because Scotland has many historical links with the tea trade with several stemming from Aberdeenshire which is where the Founders are based. When they discovered the story of James Taylor ndash a young man from the area - who grew the very first commercial tea plantation in British Ceylon, they worked with tea consultant Beverly Wainwright to source a special loose leaf tea from the Amba Estate in Sri Lanka.It is both hand-picked and hand-rolled ndash much in the same way Taylor produced his first batches  years ago on the island.When distilled, the tea provides fabulous citrus notes of blood orange along with a minty sweetness. These flavours are paired with more classic gin botanicals such as juniper, coriander seed, dried orange peel, angelica and orris root and a sprinkle of rose petals to create a smooth and fresh juniper-led gin with a citrusy lingering sweetness.The Teasmith Gin doesnrsquot disappoint. A truly smooth classic dry style gin packaged in a beautully simple bottle with lots of hidden hand-finishes ndash it ticks all the boxes.Serve this gin with copious ice, a premium quality tonic and sprig of fresh mint for a truly crisp and refreshing GT. The founders used their recent time in lockdown to completely refresh their website and provide a nice range of cocktail suggestions too! So check out the dferent ways you could enjoy The Teasmith Gin this summer.The Teasmith Gin is available through The Teasmith Ginrsquos website for pound. or through the Master of Malt. Available in store at The Good Spirit Coand Royal Mile Whiskiesand many other stockists listed on their website.Instagram:@the_teasmithTwitter: @the_teasmithFacebook:  theteasmithginFor more information, visit www.teasmithgin

title: need-stop-basking-memories-learn-live-now
story: Clutching those pictures in my hand, carefully holding the edges to avoid getting smudges on the glossy paper, rather than peering at them on a tiny digital screen, felt oddly comforting.Among the images is one of me sitting in the media tribunes, high above the Sir Chris Hoy Velodrome where I was covering the track cycling at the Glasgow  Commonwealth Games ndash exactly six years ago this weekend.It seems like another world: both literally and metaphorically. A golden summer. The Scottish independence referendum was yet to take place. There was no Brexit. People were packed into the stands like sardines and the notion of a global pandemic hadnt even crossed our minds.I look at my face in that moment and wonderI appreciated how simple le was. In truth, I was likely caught between the excitement of being at the Games and stressing about what the top line would be when I filed my report to the sports desk.In the mixed zone, journalists jostled for space, elbows and armpits an occupational hazard as the pack moved like a lumbering, multi-tentacled beast.: Susan Swarbrick: The quagmire of a socially-distanced salutationWe huddled in pens, inches from the faces of athletes still catching their breath. Sweat dripped as they ignored screaming muscles to valiantly puff out a few words. Such close proximity to other humans seems bonkers now.Scotlands Neil Fachie and Craig Maclean won two gold medals in the para-sport tandem. Their team-mates Aileen McGlynn and Louise Haston made it a double silver in the womens event, while Katie Archibald took bronze in the points race.Archibald had to briefly depart the post-race interview to go vomit in a bin ndash a peril when the body is pushed to the limit ndash but ed smiling.I appreciate you indulging me as I remember this. Im sure you have your own memories, whether at the Commonwealth Games, watching the action from home ndash or the many other landmark moments in all our lives that summer.Recent months have seen countless celebrations subdued or put on hold. Since March, Ive been as guilty as the next person of spending far more time looking back than forward.It is the polar opposite to my usual stance of skipping two or three steps ahead. Typically, Ill be daydreaming about a holiday in September, when its still July ndash or talking about Christmas when its only Halloween. Hitting pause during lockdown saw that stop.: Susan Swarbrick: Meet Susan, a pot-bellied, pyjama-wearing vision of my future selfInstead, I sought solace in the past. Yet, as much as Ive enjoyed reminiscing and taking stock, as the reel of le begins turning again, I realise it is time to move forward. But not too fast. Im finally grasping something that has always evaded me. Im slowly learning to live in the now.Our columns are a  for writers to express their opinions. They do not necessarily represent the views of The Herald

title: agenda-army-using-arts-ask-tough-questions
story: ASK people about the relationship between the Army and the arts and many will think of the paintings of historical battles that hang on gallery walls. But it extends much further and deeper ndash a prime example is Army@TheFringe. which we have run in association with Summerhall since .It enables performing artists to present shows that raise issues about le in and out of unorm, and normally takes place at the Hepburn House drill hall which we transform into an Edinburgh Fringe venue.As head of the arts for the ArmyI believe itrsquos essential for us to work with, and support, independent artists. In fact, itrsquos more important now than ever given the number and scale of concerns we all face in todayrsquos world, from racism and inequality to love, hate, peace and war.The arts have an unrivalled capacity to make us think and feel about our world ndash what it was like in the past, how it is now and where itrsquos heading. By encouraging us to ask questions of ourselves, and others, they can promote debate and lay the foundations for positive change.When Covid- forced the cancellation of the Fringe we decided to move online and refocused in order to offer some support to the artists we were already working with and to the wider performing arts sector. The result is Army@TheVirtualFringe ndash three weeks of free screenings, workshops, rehearsed readings, discussions and live-from-home performances.Some give a foretaste of productions we aim to stage next year. But many will see writers, performers, set designers, photographers, musicians and others sharing ideas and expertise with performing artists hoping to put on shows where at the Fringe ndash or indeed anywhere.With the mountainous dficulties faced by the sector right now we hope this kind of skills sharing will contribute to the efforts so many people are making to help the performing arts rebuild. And for the public we hope that what we are offering will, alongside other recently announced initiatives, provide some continuity and fill a little of the gap left by the absence of the Fringe.We also want to give something back to an arts community which has shown so much interest in Army@TheFringe and has come to us with productions of the quality of  Soldiers, The Troth and Unicorns, Almost.As a photographer myself I try to capture images that have an authenticity and express something new or dferent about people or situations. Thatrsquos very much the essence of Army@TheFringe and other initiatives through which the Army engages with the arts. They support work that is powerful, informed and independent.In some cases they do that by inviting artists who want to create work about the Army to come ldquobehind the wire and give them access to the kind of people and experiences that interest them.At other times they provide a showcase for veterans who now work in the arts and whose work reflects lived experience.Both result in an authenticity that make productions all the more affecting and persuasive whether they are addressing how families cope with death or injury, the courage of gay soldiers in coming out, womenrsquos struggle for equality or the experiences of black and overseas personnel.The result is agenda-setting art that asks tough questions about our lives and our Army ndash something that matters greatly for a healthy, open society.

title: letters-tell-us-england-plans-fix-economy
story: Scots know that the UK has a pound trillion national debt and that is before you add the conveniently ignored pound billion created through quantitative easing to rescue the corrupt banking system or the pound billion the Bank of England invented a few weeks ago to give to the Treasury or the gaping deficit there will be in this yearrsquos Westminsterrsquos annual budget because of the Covid- pandemicrsquos devastating effect on the UK GDP. Westminster hasnrsquot balanced the books for years and the impending disaster caused by Brexit will only make things worse, we understand all of that. We also know that the devolved Scottish Government balances its budget and has no control over and is incapable of directly adding to the UK national debt. Any money Scotland gets from Westminster through the Barnett formula is not English largesse but simply some of our taxes being ed to where they were gathered.I reverse the question on our Unionist friends. What we Scots want to know is what England is going to do about the financial mismanagement of the UK economy, because the elected representatives we send to Westminster to reflect the views of the Scottish people simply cannot influence in any meaningful way what Westminster does. The facts are glaringly obvious that, despite years of austerity, England has failed to address fundamental flaws in our common economy and has compounded problems that have had and are having a detrimental effect on all the parts of our supposed union of equals. The distribution of wealth and its concentration in south-east England tells one all one needs to know about the role that Westminster plays and who controls it. HS encapsulates Westminster mentality.It may seem a risky gamble for Scotland to become independent, but then again to take to the leboats in the midst of a storm may also seem risky: but the only alternative is to cower onboard and drown with the sinking ship.David J Crawford, Glasgow G.AS the independence drum continues to beat ever louder and coronavirus acts as a possible catalyst or excuse for change around the world, I cant help but feel that the time is ripe to explore what might or should become of the land we now call Scotland.I cant speak for others but, for me, Scotland is ided both culturally and historically between Highland and Lowland, East Coast and West, not to mention the distinct nature of the people of the Northern Isles and the Scottish Borders. Dferent communities with dferent identities and dferent priorities. I do not see one homogenous nation.As a person with very deep roots in the Celtic West I feel far greater affinity with the people of Ireland than I do with many of the communities further east and south. This is not a conscious choice, rather a statement of personal orientation and belonging.The people of the Highlands and Islands have had an exceptionally poor deal from Edinburgh and its Lowland bastions in recent centuries. Infor backing the wrong horse in the , our precious Highland and Hebridean heartland has been decimated, its people and language oppressed, subjugated, burnt out and cleared. Are we supposed to say thank you As we move towards a second defining vote on our constitutional future I wonderI am alone in not wanting to be a pawn in a game that involves Edinburgh replacing Westminster only for Edinburgh then to cede power to Brussels  Why would you do that  Why work so hard and build so many expectations only to achieve so little If I am to vote for change then it has to mean something tangible and not simply switching one uncaring master for another. I will not be convinced that rejoining the EU is anything other than being party to a European Project that will ultimately lead to the creation of a new country called Europe. Whither Scotia then Can I perhaps dream of a new Atlantic nation from Argyll and the Clyde Islands to Caithness with a border on the Highland line  In control of its own destiny, freed from Lowland control yet living respectfully alongside one another We have great natural resources, pure water, clean air, abundant capacity for energy generation, magnetic scenery to draw the tourists, wide open spaces, world-leading foods and whisky and, above all, brilliant people with global reach. Who knows what we can achievewe can turn dust to seed, reap our own harvest and ring our own till Ill be honest and admit that I have no idea at this stage whether or not the people of the Highlands and Islands remotely share such a vision and how this could work economically but, in an age of iconoclasm and the redefinition of identity, no Lowland politician should assume that an independent Scotland would not, in turn, find itself broken up in time by those of us wishing to assert their fundamental right to self-determination.As the creation of Holyrood emboldened nationalism, so I hope that independence will, in turn, trigger an explosion in regional identity politics within Scotland itself. One step at a time.Fraser Kelly, Millport.THERE is a simple answer to Maggie Chettys questionwhy the Prime Minster wants to hang on to Scotland. It is because that is what the people of Scotland voted for in , in a fair and free democratic referendum. You would think she might remember that.Her letter also includes a fascinating reference to the UK benefiting from ious taxes, although of course the Scottish Governments own figures tell us that Scotland gets more out of the Union by way of revenues than it puts in. The tax mentioned by Ms Chetty that is most intriguing is the one on whisky, which looks an awful lot like the mythical whisky export tax so beloved of nationalist conspiracy theorists. Likewise, she has now added a fish tax and a beef tax.Which all begs a much better question than Ms Chettys:Scottish independence is such a great idea, why do its proponents have to tell so many lies to justy it Peter A Russell, Glasgow G.THERE seems to be growing concern that interpretation of the Hate Crime Bill presently going through Holyrood would have an adverse effect on freedom of speech , particularly as regards the aspect of "stirring up hatred" Could those of us who write to The Herald then run the risk of being accused of that crime by the overly sensitive taking offence at our use of language criticising them, their views or their actions and as a consequence stirring up hatred in their own breastnot where  The letterfrom David Stubley provides an interesting case study in what to me appears to be its deliberate use of language chosen in sum to be inflammatory and personally derogatory viz ldquolackeys", "toadying", "fallacious", "lie", "charlatan parties and their willing acolytes", ldquo proven liar" and "used car salesman". In some quarters this will cause offence, even hate. Will that come to be a crime in the future Alan Fitzpatrick, Dunlop.

title: arts-reputations-liberation
story: The Daily MailSarah Vine asked why she is allowed to fly to Torremolinos in a tightly packed metal tube, breathing in other peoplersquos fumes for the best part of three hours solid mdash but am prevented from sitting in an air-conditioned auditorium "Itrsquos not just illogical, itrsquos absurd," she said. "Especially given whatrsquos at stake. Of all the things I miss about the old le, live culture is perhaps the greatest."She said that, enjoyable as Netflix is, nothing beats the excitement of a live performance."There is an intimacy and honesty to live performance that screen pixels, however slick, can never quite match, a human connection that feels so very vital mdash particularly now itrsquos gone," she added. "Therersquos something  too, of course: If we donrsquot find a way mdash any way mdash of getting our venues open again and our audiences cheering, we risk turning our rich, cultural scene into a barren desert."In order to try and help save the situation, Andrew Lloyd Webber staged an invitation only Beverley Knight concert in the London Palladium, she said, with  people in a , capacity venue, complete with one-way system, temperature checks and rows of seats sealed off.It feels weird to be sitting alone, surrounded by empty chairs," she said. "I clap a bit and nod my head dutully in time to the music mdash but feel stupid and exposed." Lloyd Webberrsquos message is clear: theatres cannot survive under these conditions. For any show to break even it has to run at least  per cent capacity. Todayrsquos auditorium is at  per cent."If the Government doesnrsquot give theatres the same freedoms as restaurants, pubs, gyms, tattoo parlours and the rest, they may never re-open ... and Covid will have destroyed our culture."The Frederick Forsyth said the Government is shuddering at the now unpreventable appearance of a penetrating and impartial assessment of the past seven months."More peacocks and more reputations are sheltering behind the pretence that the Covid outbreak was skilfully handled," he said. "But the politicos are the tip of the iceberg and can claim they were only following the best advice, or, as they put it "following the science"."He said the post-mortem report will reveal that people were conned into unnecessary panic, with mind-numbing propaganda and economic ruin by blitheringly incompetent administrators, bumbling quangos and "scientists" straight out of the annals of Mystic Meg.He said the unstoppable release of the report would lead to the fall of the hard rain referred to by Dominic Cummings."It is an attempt to persuade the panic and the consequent frightened obedience to stupid rules to continue that lies behind the new "scientic predictions" of a massive autumn spike in Covid," he added. "Those analysts who were rebuffed early on, and who were proved to be right, are saying this will be mainly the annual seasonal winter flu wave. This has been a tragic but never nation-destroying phenomenon for many, many years. The chances are that these losses will be presented to us as Covid deaths - to preserve reputations on high."The IndependentCaroline Harrap said the reaction to the mandatory wearing of face masks from yesterday in England was mixed at best."As someone who is prone to the occasional bout of anxiety, I feared it would affect my ability to breatheor make myself understood ," she said. "But then, in Morrisons the other day, something strange happened. As I strolled down the fruit and veg aisle, pondering my newfound anonymity, I felt a sudden sense of liberation rather than restriction."Who could seeshe bought two packs of fries, she said, when no one could actually see her "Hidden behind a mask, everyone is equal in the supermarket ndash regardless of their purchasing choices," she said.And, on another level, she feels free to go about her business without being judged on her appearance by others, male or female."A bit like wearing a school unorm, I suppose, suddenly we are all starting from the same place," she said."Wearing a face mask is, as it turns out, a great leveller."

title: campaigners-call-scottish-government-ban-lgbt-conversion-therapy
story: They said the widelydiscredited practice ndash which seeks to change someones sexuality or gender identity ndash is a "risk to public health" and should be made a criminal offence.It comes after Prime Minister Boris Johnson called conversion therapy "absolutely abhorrent" and said the UK Government willbring forward plans to ban it.Stars such as Sir Elton John have also recently backed calls to outlaw it.A petition has now been lodged in Holyrood calling on the Scottish Government to take action, attracting thousands of signatures and support from high-profile LGBT organisations.Tristan Gray, one of those named on the petition, said:"We only discovered that its not already illegal quite recently, and we were quite shocked by it."The Scottish Government said conversion therapy is "unethical, harmful and has no place in Scotland".However, it said the legislative timetable for the current parliamentary session "is currently fully committed".It said it "fully support moves by the UK Government to end conversion therapy" and will engage with officials ondevolved and reserved responsibilities.Gray,who is on the Scottish Greens policy committee, said conversion therapy is "putting someone through a process that would erase their LGBT identity".He pointed to moves to ban it in Canada, where officials have defined it as seeking "to change an inidualrsquos sexual orientation to heterosexual, to repress or reduce non-heterosexual attraction or sexual behaviours, or to change an inidualrsquos gender identity to match the sex they were assigned at birth".The Canadian legislation, which was introduced earlier this year, proposes five new criminal offences related to conversion therapy.These include causing a minor to undergo conversion therapy,causing a person to undergo it against their will and profiting from or advertising conversion therapy.The Holyrood petitioners insist the practice has "damaged generations of LGBT+ young people and adults and continues to do so".They quoted a report from the charity Stonewall, which found  per cent of health and care staff had witnessed colleagues expressing the view that lesbian, gay and bisexual people can be ldquocured of their sexual orientation.They also referenced a survey by theOzanne Foundation, which works withreligious organisations to eliminate discrimination based on sexuality or gender.This found .% of respondents had ldquobeen advised to consider attempts to change their sexual orientationand just over one in sevenhad ldquovoluntarily considered it.The petitioners said: "Concerningly, .% of LGBT+ respondents had been forced to go through attempts to change their sexual orientation."Almost two-thirds, .%, had "suffered from mental health issues" as a result of the conversion therapy, including nearly a third who said they had attempted suicide.The Holyrood petition notes: "These responses clearly show that there is a signicant public health case for banning conversion therapy."The experiences of those who were put through this practice show that enforcing this ban should fall under criminal law."Both of these areas fall within the devolved powers of the Scottish Parliament."It said the UK Government has yet to act despite committing to end the practice years ago.It added: "Given this information, it is clear that conversion therapy is a risk to public health, especially the mental health of vulnerable young adults and children."There is broad support for its criminalisation by those who have been subjected to it, and, as healthcare and criminal justice matter, we believe it to be within the scope of the Scottish Governmentrsquos powers to ensure this practice is brought to an end."Gray raised concerns the UK plans will be kicked into the long grass.The -year-old said: "I think it should fall under criminal law, and that is something that is shared by people who have undergone it."People who have been through conversion therapy overwhelmingly support it being banned, and I think half of them support it being an area for criminal law."I think they are the people who should be listened to on this."People who have been subjected to conversion therapy should be the people we listen to most."I think it should come down under criminal law, and I think the justication for that partly includes it being a public health issue."He said it is an issue that should gain "universal support" from Scotlands political parties.Jordan Daly, co-founder of Time for Inclusive Education , a charity working to address anti-LGBT bullying in schools, is one of those backing the petition.He said: ldquoConversion or reparative therapies should have been outlawed a long time ago, and practices which ly claim to change, cure or repair an inidualrsquos sexual orientation or gender identity or expression have been shown time and again to be emotionally and psychologically traumatic on those who have experienced and survived such programs."He said practices which rely on "using emotionally exploitative tactics to encourage feelings of shame and repression in iniduals are active in Scotland right now".He added: "We support this petition and the efforts of campaigners to continue raising awareness about the existence of dangerous and shameful practices in our country."Scotland has an opportunity to lead the UK here, and ensure that no other LGBT person, young or old, experiences this ndash ministers and parliamentarians should not delay in taking it.SNP equalities minister Christina McKelvie said: ldquoWe do not support or advocate the practice of conversion therapy."It is unethical, harmful and has no place in Scotland."We fully support moves by the UK Government to end conversion therapy, and are engaging with them as they develop proposals.ldquoThe legislative timetable for the current parliamentary session is currently fully committed."We are continuing to engage with officials in the UK Government on their thinking as it develops, and this will include consideration of devolved and reserved responsibilities as they relate to this practice.

title: big-read-pen-mightier-sword-political-cartoons-needed-ever
story: IN November , Lord Halax, the British foreign secretary, ed to Britain after meeting Joseph Goebbels. Halax, an architect of appeasement, wanted to ensure peace between Nazi Germany and Britain. One of his first tasks after the Berlin trip was to contact the publishers of the Evening Standard about the problematic matter of a cartoonist called David Low.Throughout the s, Low had lampooned Hitler in the pages of the British press. Halax told the Standard: ldquoYou cannot imagine the frenzy these cartoons cause. As soon as a copy of the Evening Standard arrives, it is pounced on for Lowrsquos cartoons, andit is of Hitler, as it usually is, telephones buzz, tempers rise, fevers mount, and the whole government system of Germany is in uproar.Nobody at the paper would rein in Low, so it fell to Halax to intercede personally. He took Low to lunch and laid his cards on the table. Low listened and replied: ldquoDo I understand you to say that you would find it easier to promote peacemy cartoons did not irritate the Nazi leaders personally Halax said yes. Low later explained: ldquoOf course, he was the foreign secretary hellip So I said, lsquoVery well, I donrsquot want to be responsible for a world warrsquo.In his own words, Low ldquoslowed down a bit. That didnrsquot last long, though. No cartoonist could resist satirising Hitler. Kicking the living hell out of power is part of the job description, after all.Soon Low would go on to draw his masterpiece, ldquoRendezvous, which satirised the grotesquely cynical peace deal between Hitler and Stalin ndash the Nazi-Soviet non-aggression pact that helped pave the path to war. In the cartoon, Hitler and Stalin are shown courteously meeting each other across a dead body. Hitler doffs his cap and says charmingly, ldquoThe scum of the earth, I believe . Stalin replies, with equal grace, ldquoThe bloody assassin of the workers, I presume .Low understood exactly the power of his pen. He once said: ldquoNo dictator is inconvenienced or even displeased by cartoons showing his terrible person stalking through blood and mud. That is the kind of idea about himself that the power-seeking world-beater would want to propagate. It not only feeds his vanity, but unfortunately it shows profitable s in an awed world. What he does not want to get around is the idea that he is an ass, which is really damaging. And there, in one historical vignette, the power of the political cartoon is neatly summed up.Bye bye BellTherersquos been much worry over the future of satire in Britain and the rest of the Western world of late, as so-called cancel culture wends its way through all avenues of the media from film to print. A short while ago, it emerged thatnewspaper was not to renew the contract of its cartoonist Steve Bell. The move came not long after the departure of a senior editor at another bastion of the so-called liberal press, The New York Times. James Bennet had published a piece by a republican senator calling for military force to put down violent protests. It caused outrage. He resigned. A high-profile columnist with the paper then also resigned. Bari Weiss claimed the paper was effectively being edited by Twitterrsquos ldquowoke brigade.Steve Bellrsquos cartooning is brutal, hersquos cruel. Depending on your political point of view, hersquos a comic genius one day, an utter villain the next. His withering caricatures can define a politician and overshadow their career. Bellrsquos portrayal of John Major wearing his Y-fronts over his trousers summed up the mediocrity of the man as Prime Minister. Hersquos drawn David Cameron as a human condom, and George Osborne as an SM gimp. His portrayal of Alex Salmond as a Saltire-faced, tartan oaf riled nationalists during the  referendum. Likewise, his cartoon of Margaret Thatcher, after her death, sliding into hell and asking ldquowhy is this pit still open  outraged Conservatives.Deliberately upsetting people, using nasty stereotypes, punching below the belt ndash when it comes to dealing with power Bell, like most great cartoonists, is happy to use any tactic. However, hersquos also faced opprobrium over some of his cartoons such as one showing Israeli leader Benjamin Netanyahu holding Tony Blair like a glove puppet. The cartoon was seen as playing with anti-Semitic tropes. Recently his caricature of Home Secretary Priti Patel also got him in serious trouble. He drew Patel quite literally as a fat cow, complete with a ring in her nose. As Patel is of Hindu origin, and the cow scared in Hinduism, he brought fury down upon himself.Soon, amid newspaper layoffs, it emerged that his contract was scheduled not to be renewed. The Jewish Chronicle reported that the moves were ldquosaid to be unrelated to the latest round of redundancies. In June , Bell clashed with rsquos top executives when he complained that he felt ldquounfairly traduced and censored after the paper wouldnrsquot run a cartoon showing a Palestinian burning in a fireplace while Netanyahu and Theresa May sit talking. Bell said editor Katharine Viner did ldquonot really have an argument for spiking his drawing.A few days ago, Bell himself tweeted that his departure was nothing to do with Patel, but rather job cuts at the paper. However, his loss has prompted many in the media to speculate that hersquos another scalp for cancel culture.Wicked clownsIf the political cartoonist has an historical ancestor, itrsquos the court jester. In the medieval court, the jester could get away with anything. The jester could mock royalty, insult palace favourites, and point out the failings of everyone from bishops to potentates. Sometimes, jesters lost their heads, but mostly their patrons welcomed their caustic comedy. It reminded the powerful that they were human and could make stupid mistakes just like the rest of us.Of course, throughout the history of cartooning, not all artists have worked for the greater good or held power to account. Some have acted in bad faith and given succour to dictators like the cartoonists for Nazi newspapers such as Der Sturmer which drew Jews as devils and snakes.The most important issue for any political cartoon is this: what direction itrsquos punching. Is it punching up ndash at the powerful, greedy and dangerous  Or punching down at the weak  If we agree that punching up is the right thing to do ndash then is any tactic fair game  Can stereotypes be used  Until not so long ago, we expected cartoonists to deploy any trick in the book as long as they hit their mark ndash and most importantly made us laugh and think. Now, times are changing. Will that lessen the power of satire at a time when we need it most ndash in an era of populism, hate mobs, and unaccountable power and wealth  The bottom-line question for today is this: can a cartoon really workit is so sanitised that it upsets absolutely nobody The art of offenceIn his excellent book, The Art Of Controversy: Political Cartoons And Their Enduring Power, the American journalist Victor Navasky tells a story which sums up the impossibility of ever finding a cartoon which both hits its mark and offends nobody.Navasky was editing the US magazine The Nation when cartoonist David Levine brought him a drawing of Henry Kissinger ndash the former US secretary of state, seen by many on the left as a warmonger. The cartoon, ldquoScrewing the World, depicted the body of a woman with a head like a globe of the world lying on a bed, her fingers clutching the sheets. On top of her, his body just covered by a Stars and Stripes blanket, is Kissinger, his face contorted with wolfish pleasure. For some, the image absolutely expresses Kissingerrsquos treatment of the world. For others, and in this case many of the Nationrsquos staff, it was sexist and unacceptable.Navasky was collared by his team and asked: ldquoWhy isnrsquot he doing it to a Third World male Good question. But, of course,Kissinger had been shown raping an African man, itrsquos pretty obvious where the anger would come from regarding that reworked cartoon.A history of mischief and sufferingCartoons have been about since Egypt in BC ndash and theyrsquore always grotesque, cruel and offensive. Asking for a cartoonist not to cause offence is like asking a bird not to fly ndash itrsquos innate.Despite ancient caricaturists leaving scratchings in stone mocking almighty leaders like the Pharaoh Akhenaten, the political cartoon is really a creature of the modern age, finding its feet in the s with the English artists William Hogarth and James Gillray. Hogarth satirised society. He was a moralist who tried to expose the failings of the people ndash both rich and poor ndash in works like A Harlotrsquos Progress, A Rakersquos Progress and Gin Lane, a vision of a barbarous drunken London where alcohol is more important than the lives of children.Gillray had two main targets: the excesses of the French Revolution, and the greed of the British ruling class. In his cartoon The Plumb Pudding in Danger he shows the British Prime Minister William Pitt carving up the world with Napoleon. In other European countries at the time, such mockery could have ended with the artist on the gallows. Gillrayrsquos cartoon A Voluptuary Under the Horrors of Digestion portrays a fat, greedy, spoilt Prince Regent, who would go on to be George IV. When Gillray felt the press was too grovelling towards the Duchess of York he drew the cartoon The Duchessrsquos Little Shoes Yielding to the Magnitude of the Dukersquos Foot ndash which effectively showed the aristocratic pair having sex.By the early th century, cartoons were a staple of every newspaper in the democratic world. The cartoon was there to both reflect the politics of the paper and its readers, and to challenge their beliefs. Readers expected their daily cartoon to cause offence ndash either to them or others. And matters effectively stayed like that for the next century ndash although of course the cartoon went underground behind the Iron Curtain as it satirised the absurdities of Soviet le.Perhaps, the greatest practitioner of the modern cartoon is Ralph Steadman. Now aged , Steadman skewered the powerful from the late-s onwards. For instance, in his inimitable surreal, ink-splattered style he nailed the fear brought about by the rise of the former Hollywood actor Ronald Reagan to the US presidency.In Reaganrsquos Latest Close-Up, the President looms over Lady Liberty, holding her in a movie star embrace, while dressed as Dracula, his teeth sharp and ready to bite.But cartooning never comes without its cost. In , the Palestinian cartoonist Naji al-Ali ndash who lambasted both Israel and the PLO ndash was murdered on his way to work. In , the Sri Lankan cartoonist Jfry Yoonoos was beaten and stabbed. In , Yemenrsquos Saleh Ali was arrested after he published a cartoon showing a Yemeni man being arrested as one policeman declared ldquoDemocracy is what I say. In Cameroon, Belarus, Iran, and Syria, cartoonists have been subjected to violence, censorship and persecution.Some have said that the clash between cartooning and Islam represents the ultimate expression of cancel culture ndash the act of murdering someone because they caused you offence in art form.In , Denmarkrsquos Jyllands-Posten newspaper published cartoons mocking Islam. Many depicted Mohammed and were seen by Muslims as blasphemous. Death threats were made, cartoonists went into hiding, demonstrations began around the world. By , an estimated  people had been killed as a result of protests and anger.Some years later, in , the satirical French magazine, Charlie Hebdo, published a caricature of Mohammed on its front cover. Its offices were firebombed. In , the magazine published more cartoons deemed offensive to Islam. In January , Islamist terrorists attacked the magazinersquos office. Twelve people died, including cartoonists Cabu and Charb.In the immediate wake of the attack, the West embraced the slogan ldquoJe Suis Charlie as an expression of solidarity with artists murdered simply for daring to draw what they thought. However, quickly, that slogan began to stale for some.There are many who would now no longer stand with Charlie. The Catholic League for Religious and Civil Liberties went into victim-blaming mode. ldquoKilling in response to insult, no matter how gross, must be unequivocally condemned. That is why what happened in Paris cannot be tolerated. But neither should we tolerate the kind of intolerance that provoked this violent reaction, said its president Bill Donohue. He was not the only such voice.In this era of social media and political extremism, when offence-taking is as ubiquitous as sand on a beach, cartoonists find themselves in the crosshairs more than ever before in the Western world.When it comes to free speech, cartoons are often ugly speech. But thatrsquos the point ndash theyrsquore meant to offend. Andugly, offensive speech isnrsquot defended, what happens to the concept of free speech  A silent world without offence really would be no laughing matter.

title: ticket-prices-look-set-soar-venues-look-survive-post-pandemic-landscape
story: Mass gatherings were the first social events to be banned by the Scottish Government in March as the realities of the Covid- crisis first swept across the country ndash and venues desperate to sell tickets to stay afloat are yet to reopen and havenrsquot even been handed a timescale of when they are likely to begin performances again.Festival bosses in Edinburgh, where all internationally-acclaimed summer events have been scrapped due to the pandemic, have warned MSPs that any plans to reopen venues with social distancing measures in place should include ldquoan exploration of either reduced or relaxed social distancing measures.:Barrowlands wonrsquot be allowed to die ndash well be backIn evidence submitted to Holyroodrsquos culture committee, the Edinburgh International Festival added that this relaxation should be ldquocoupled with the creation of a comprehensive set of guidance and equipment to enable venues to stage mass gatherings safely.The organisation has warned that ticket prices for cultural events could soar to mitigate costs and lack of revenue for venues.They added: ldquoThis may require help with the additional costs of staging safe events, including extra security and stewarding, pre-event checks, accommodation and equipment costs, and increased labour costs. These costs may amount to several pounds per attendee, an additional burden that will be impossible for nearly all venues in the sector to absorb.ldquoTherefore, it may be necessary to establish a subsidy for social measures, recognising venues can only operate at -% capacity at two metres distancing and -% at just one metre.Music venues in particular will struggle to make enough money to be viable with any sort of social distancing being required.Mark Davyd, chief executive of the Music Venue Trust, said: ldquoThe issue of the additional cost per attendee is certainly a concern and needs addressing.ldquoWe would highlight that at one metre, social distancing grass-roots music venues that are able to open, which is approximately one third of the spaces, can operate at an average % capacity. Operating at these capacities requires not only investment in those able to attend, but also in meeting the challenges presented by losing % of available income on each event.:The Glaswegians aiming to turn the Gallowgate into the new FinniestonldquoMost events will simply not be commercially viable without signicant subsidy in a sector in which profit margins were already very low.The Barrowland in Glasgow has previously warned that social distancing at the venue, with a capacity of ,, is a ldquototal nightmare.The Scottish Government has handed over pound. million to grassroots music venues to keep them afloat until October, but no further support has been promised. Ministers have also made a poundm pot of funding available for performing arts venues that have been hit by lockdown.The organisation added: ldquoDespite much in the way of plans and guidance being developed for what a lsquosafersquomay look like, the reality is that it is unlikely to be economically viable for many live venues to open under social distancing guidance.The Royal Scottish National Orchestra has warned that once performances are able to restart, ldquoit is likely that any continued social distancing requirements will impact the size of orchestra we can field.Theatres across Scotland have been severely impacted by lockdown ndash with the Tron Theatre in Glasgow predicting it will lose up to pound, this year.At the Kingrsquos Theatre in Edinburgh, poundm renovation plans are now under threat ndash with poundm of the funding set to come from a levy on non-existent ticket sales.Fiona Gibson, chief executive of Capital Theatres said the project is now at risk as ldquoa large element of the fund will likely be repurposed for the organisationrsquos survival.She added: ldquoIn our view there is no such thing as a socially distant theatre.ldquoFor the last , years, people have got together to share the same experience in the same space at the same time. Theatre buildings are designed on that premise.ldquoTo have performers socially distant would demand creation from scratch of an entirely new repertoire of work right across all performance genres.She added: ldquoFor obvious reasons large gatherings were first to close down, in the same vein we anticipate theatres to be the last to open up again.ldquoFrom having spoken to our network of venue operators across the country, the general consensus, at this point in time, is that March or April  is the most likely date for the theatre industry to restart.ldquoMargins for Capital Theatres, as a large-scale commercial operator, are tight. The success of our business model requires in the region of , audience visitors per year. Our ability to continue trading with what, at best, could be -% capacity in our auditoriums, allowing for distancing, simply does not stack up. The recovery timescale for theatre is clearly going to be longer than some sectors. We are still in crisis and will be until we can recover audiences and move forwards into adaptation and then recovery.

title: russia-scottish-question-timeline
story: Scotland votes by a -point margin to remain part of the UK. There has been lots of political rhetoric about Vladimir Putinrsquos regime trying to nudge voters one way or another in the referendum.But the first properly documented Kremlin operation comes immediately after the vote: by starting and then amplying claims the poll was rigged. The narrative took off. This comes after an internationally criticised plebiscite in Crimea after its forced annexation by Putin earlier that year.September A new media outlet, the brainchild of Kremlin propaganda chief Dmitri Kiselyov, announces that it is to open a base in Edinburgh. Sputnik moves to hire locals, including Scottish independence supporters, though many subsequently leave. Former employees last week told The Times that its newsroom was ldquoshambolic. Meanwhile, the SNP shuns an overture from a Moscow campaign group close to the Kremlin and refuses to attend a ldquoseparatist summit in the Russian capital.June Britain votes for Brexit. Some Remainers and observers accuse Russia of amplying anti-EU sentiment. Last weekrsquos Russia Report revealed no serious study has been carried out on this.May A conference convened in the Scottish Parliament hears anonymised expert views from Moscow that Russian propaganda will move against the SNP after Brexit.:Kremlin mouthpiece sets up UK base in EdinburghNovember Nicola Sturgeon is understood to be distraught as her former mentor and predecessor Alex Salmond unveils a show on Russian state TV RT as the channel recruits celebrities to boost its credibility. A senior SNP politician, then MEP Alyn Smith, responds with an F-word, for the record. Opposition leaders round on both Salmond and Sturgeon.Some Russia watchers whisper that this - among other things - could be seen as an attack on the SNP by widening internal party isions.December As it becomes clearer that Russia was behind the claims the  vote was rigged, the SNP announces that it would be naive to assume the current Russian government was not trying to intervene in Scottish politics.:SNP claims Russia is likely to have interfered in referendumMarch Senior SNP figures claim that Nicola Sturgeon has come under attack from Kremlin trolls masquerading as lsquocybernats after she condemns the Russian Government over the attempted assassination of former double agents Sergei Skripal and his daughter Yulia.:SNP top brass warn: Sturgeon is being targeted by Kremlin trollsAugust A leading expert in Russian social media disinformation campaigns looks at a group of online sockpuppet accounts amplying conspiracy theories about Alex Salmond on Twitter and concludes they are Scottish, not Russian. His findings are repeatedly ly misrepresented in the Scottish blogosphere as an attempt to paint local McBots as Kremlin operatives.:Meet the McBots: how Scottish cyber activists try to game TwitterAugust Senior SNP frontbenchers continue to criticise the Russian government over its war in Ukraine and its human rights record at home as relations between Edinburgh and Moscow sour further.In a message aimed at Scottish nationalists who still consume RT and Sputnik, the partyrsquos defence spokesman Stewart McDonald, tweets: ldquoIf yoursquore on RT then yoursquore on the side of the oppressor against the oppressed.March Salmond is acquitted of sex charges at the High Court in Edinburgh. It emerges that RT had sought to do opinion polling on his guilt or innocence. The channelrsquos head had previously tried to link charges against to his work for the Russian broadcaster.

title: tributes-paid-fleetwood-mac-guitarist-peter-green
story: Fleetwood and Green formed the influential group in London in , alongside John McVie and Jeremy Spencer.Green, who has died at the age of , later left the band after struggling with his mental health. In a statement to the PA news agency, Fleetwood said: ldquoFor me, and every past and present member of Fleetwood Mac, losing Peter Green is monumental.ldquoPeter was the man who started the band Fleetwood Mac along with myself, John McVie, and Jeremy Spencer. No one has ever stepped into the ranks of Fleetwood Mac without a reverence for Peter Green and his talent, and to the fact that music should shine bright and always be delivered with uncompromising passion.Fleetwood, , added: ldquoPeter, I will miss you, but rest easy your music lives on. I thank you for asking me to be your drummer all those years ago. We did good, and trail blazed one hell of a musical road for so many to enjoy.ldquoGod speed to you, my dearest friendhelliphellip. Love Mick Fleetwood.Green, the influential blues rock guitarist, whose songs included Albatross and Oh Well, was born in Londonrsquos Bethnal Green into a Jewish family.He formed Fleetwood Mac with drummer Fleetwood in London in , after a stint in John Mayallrsquos Bluesbreakers ndash filling in for Eric Clapton.pic QHfatVDUUGreen and Fleetwood wanted John McVie to join the group on bass, and named the band Fleetwood Mac to entice him ndash a strategy that was ultimately successful.Under his direction, the band produced three albums and a series of well-loved tracks including Black Magic Woman, Man Of The World and Oh Well.Green penned the instrumental Albatross, which remains Fleetwood Macrsquos only UK number one single, hitting the top of the charts in January .Carlos Santanarsquos  version of Black Magic Woman, in which he added conga and timbales drums, became one of the Mexican-Americanrsquos biggest hits.Green left Fleetwood Mac after a final performance in  as he struggled with mental health dficulties and spiralling drug use, later sleeping rough.He was eventually diagnosed with schizophrenia and spent time in hospitals undergoing electro-convulsive therapy during the mid-s.Most sadly have lost one of the most tasteful guitar players ever I have always been a huge admirer of the great Peter Green may he rest in peace.mdash Peter FramptonJuly , The band continued with a transformed line-up featuring a core group of Fleetwood, Stevie Nicks, Lindsey Buckingham, John McVie and Christine McVie.This phase gave rise to their huge albums Fleetwood Mac and Rumours.Green emerged from obscurity on a number of occasions, forming the Peter Green Splinter Group in the late s with Nigel Watson and Cozy Powell.They released nine albums between  and .Speaking to the PA news agency in , Fleetwood described Green as ldquoa major talent that to this day holds out.He added: ldquoI consider myself very lucky to have even played with him.ldquoOf course it upsets me but therersquos nothing I can do about it. Itrsquos his le. I havenrsquot seen him for years.Green was among the eight members mdash along with Fleetwood, Nicks, Buckingham, the McVies, Danny Kirwan and Jeremy Spencer mdash inducted into the Rock  Roll Hall of Fame in .Earlier this year, artists including Fleetwood, Aerosmithrsquos Steven Tyler, Pink Floydrsquos David Gilmour, ZZ Toprsquos Billy Gibbons and guitarists Jonny Lang and Andy Fairweather Low performed at the London Palladium during a gig celebrating the early years of Fleetwood Mac and Green.Green married Jane Samuels in January . They orced in  and share a daughter.Singer and guitarist Peter Frampton was among those paying tribute.He said: ldquoMost sadly have lost one of the most tasteful guitar players ever I have always been a huge admirer of the great Peter Green may he rest in peace.Mumford and Sons guitarist Winston Marshall also tweeted a touching tribute, thanking Green ldquofor the music.He wrote: ldquoRIP Peter Green. #GOAT . Man of the world, oh well, albatross, need your love so bad. Some of my favourites songs and performances of all time. Thank you for the music.And Black Sabbathrsquos Geezer Butler described Green as ldquoone of the greats.

title: POLITICS WATCH    Guess who is taking on Mrs Thatcher s role as backseat driver
story: Margaret Thatcher reckoned she had been a ldquovery good backseat driver after John Major took her perch. He saw it dferently, calling her interventions ldquointolerable.The Thatcher-Major tussle was something of an exception, with most past leaders taking care not to criticise from the sidelines. Yet the rules, as well as being unwritten, are fluid. Mr Major himself threatened to take Boris Johnson to court for proroguing parliament.Tony Blair has fast become the past premier most likely to pop up with ldquohelpful advice, as he showed on Sky Newsrsquos Ridge on Sunday.With the BBC Sunday programmes now on their summer hols, presenter Sophy Ridge made the most of being the only show in town, breezing straight in on the dayrsquos big story ndash the sudden imposition of a fortnightrsquos quarantine for holidaymakers ing from Spain. Among those caught out by the rule change was Englandrsquos Transport Secretary, Grant Shapps.Jon Ashworth, Shadow Health Secretary, called the Governmentrsquos performance ldquoshambolic."There are holidaymakers in Spain at the moment confused and distressed, there are people about to go on holiday to Spain and the islands like Tenere who are confused, and they dont know whether their employers will allow them to take two weeks quarantine. The Government is just saying, We hope that employers co-operate. I hope I win the lottery on Saturday but that doesnt mean it is going to happen.Dominic Raab, the Foreign Secretary, was a hasty addition to the line-up. On a typical Sunday, Ridge has to make do with grabbing pavement interviews with Ministers when they are on their way to The Andrew Marr Show. This time, Mr Raab was live in the studio, at the requisite two metre social distance.No worker following quarantine guidance should be penalised by employers, he said, including by being put onto sick pay."If someone is following the law in relation to quarantine and self-isolating the way they should, they cant have penalties taken against them."As for his ministerial colleague Mr Shapps being caught on the hop, the Foreign Secretary said it showed the risks for everyone.Mr Raab could not guarantee other countries would follow Spain and be taken off the ldquosafe list."All we can say is weve got this Joint Biosecurity Centre, we monitor the risk in real time, we take decisive swt action and so there is an element of uncertainty this summerpeople go abroad. He will be staying at home over the recess.Tony Blair had the sun-smooched visage of the international globetrotter. Either that or he has been spending a lot of time in one of his back gardens. The latter seems unlikely given how busy he seems to be with the modestly titled Tony Blair Institute for Global Change. Its latest position paper, Learning to Live Alongside Covid-, was ostensibly the reason for his latest appearance.It was a wide-ranging interview covering everything from Russia and China to Scottish independence. You can read what he had to say in full where in the paper, but in summary: Boris Johnson was uselessScottish Labour had been uselessand current Labour leader Keir Starmer was proving usefulIt was fairly predictable stuff for the former Prime Minister, except for the end when Ridge asked why he could not seem to wrench himself away from politics. Isnrsquot it time to take a break, she wondered, go round the golf course or to the shepherdrsquos hut  David Cameron famously opted for the latter, spending a cool pound, on one for his Cotswolds garden.Mr Blair seemed momentarily taken aback. ldquoItrsquos not something I want to do. A lot of people might think thatrsquos exactly what he should do, stop talking about things. But I care about the country, I think we are at a huge moment of change in the world.Addressing the elephant backseat passenger in the room, he went on: ldquoIrsquove tried to do something that previous prime ministers have not done, but in the future I predict that many more will try and do because you leave office when yoursquove still got a lot of years of active working le.ldquoI always say to peopleyou donrsquot want to listen to me itrsquos a free world, donrsquot bother."But Irsquom not going to be playing rounds of golf or sitting twiddling my thumbs. Thatrsquos not going to happen ever.One was reminded of what Mrs Thatcher said after the  election, that she hoped to ldquogo on and on.Keir Starmer will be delighted.

title: bbc-urged-drop-sturgeons-politicised-daily-covid-briefings
story: The party claimed they were "in breach of the Charter of the BBC".The Scottish Toriesalso accused Ms Sturgeon of using the briefings, which attract , viewers across two TV channels, to ldquopromote SNP policy and stir up resentment against the UK Government.Initially held each day, the Scottish Government briefings were recently cut back to three per week, but are expected to increase when schoolsfrom August .Labour complained earlier this month to Donalda MacKinnon, the BBCrsquos director in Scotland, that the First Minister was using the unprecedented airtime to score political points.Scottish Labour deputy Jackie Baillie told Ms MacKinnon the sht in content made ita ldquohugely inappropriate use of public money ten  months from a Hoyrood election.:No coronavirus deaths in Scotland for tenth day in a rowThe Dumbartshire MSP said she felt very strongly that the briefings cannot be allowed to continue in their current format.In recent weeks, economy secretary Fiona Hyslop has also appeared in the briefings to announce funding measures for Scottish businesses and the arts.Ms Sturgeon, iniably at the prompting of the media covering the briefings, has also commented on Boris Johnson, the Union, independence and Russian disinformation.Support for independence has rise to  per cent since the briefings began, and Ms Sturgeonrsquos personal approval ratings have soared.In reply to Labour, Ms MacKinnon last week said the BBC also broadcast UK Government and Welsh First Ministerrsquos daily briefings, and the pandemic remained ldquofar from over.Refusing Ms Bailliersquos demand, she said: ldquoIt is clear that information and advice from the Scottish Government and from the health authorities, necessarily, continues to evolve and, in such circumstances, it it important that we continue to provide public access to the Government briefings.Scottish Labour peer George Foulkes said the response was ldquototally unsatisfactory and has now written back to the BBC demanding a meeting with Ms MacKinnon.In a letter to Luke McCullough, BBC Scotlandrsquos Parliamentary  Corporate Affairs Manager, Lord Foulkes said he, Ms Baillie and Shadow Scottish Secretary Ian Murray had all written to the corporation ldquoexpressing concern about the First Ministerrsquos televised briefings.Writing in his capacity as chair of the Scottish Group of the Parliamentary Labour Party, he said: ldquoThese briefings, which are meant to be for providing information to the public about the pandemic, have become increasingly party political with no opportunity for the right of reply for Opposition parties in Scotland.ldquoIn the past week for example Fiona Hyslop used the briefing to announce grants in the Borders, Dumfries and Galloway and the Northern and Western Isles and the First Minister used the briefing to comment critically on the visit to Scotland by the Prime Minister.ldquoAll of this and more are clearly outwith the purpose of the briefings and in breach of the Charter of the BBC.:Brexit: Petition launched calling for European Union flag to be removed fromoutside Scottish Government buildingsHe said the reply to Ms Baillie last week was one ldquowhich we all find totally unsatisfactory.He concluded: ldquoAccordingly I am writing to seek an urgent meeting with Donalda where the three of us can express our concerns directly.Scottish Tory leader Jackson Carlaw also weighed into the row, saying the briefings had become ldquoincreasingly redundant and were being used by Mr Sturgeon to promote the SNP.He said: ldquoEveryone understood the need for these daily briefings when the outbreak happened, and in the fast-moving months that followed.ldquoBut theyrsquove become increasingly redundant, and are developing into a regular opportunity for Nicola Sturgeon to promote SNP policy and stir up resentment towards the UK Government.ldquoThe BBC needs to stop pretending there is justication for unquestioningly screening what are rapidly becoming SNP party political broadcasts.A BBC Scotland spokesman said: ldquoWe are broadcasting Scottish Government briefings on the pandemic ad the easing of lockdown because these are matters of signicant public interest.ldquoWhile cases of infection may be decreasing from their peak during the pandemic, there remains a valid editorial justication for reporting public health information and asking questions on new developments, such as the recent clusters in the Borders and Lanarkshire.ldquoThe briefings in Scotland are covered by BBC one - which has also been the case when the UK and Welsh governments have held briefings.ldquoViewing figures indicate there is a continuing audience need and appetite for information on the crisis, with an average daily combined audience of , for the briefings on both BBC One Scotland and the BBC Scotland channel.A Scottish Government spokesperson said: ldquoDaily media briefings continue to be the most used source of information about the Covid- pandemic in Scotland and are used to disseminate the latest public health guidance as well as essential information about services and support for people and the economy.ldquoThe briefings also provide an opportunity for rigorous scrutiny from the media with  to  journalists participating every day.

title: refugee-doctor-covid-19-frontline-scotland-pleads-aid-end-horror-syria
story: Dr Ahmed Subeh fled Damascus at the height of the Syriarsquos conflict, leaving his we and parents to take his chance as a refugee in Europe.He risked his le travelling through Lebanon and Turkey before joining a small boat crammed with  refugees to Samos in Greece. He then managed to get onto two dferent flights, first to Paris and then from Italy onto Edinburgh Airport where he claimed asylum in .After being housed in Glasgow he then put his mind to learning better English and completing his medical studies to be a doctor in Scotland ndash then successfully gained a job at Aberdeen Royal Infirmary two years ago.He has been reunited with his we, Dana and they now live happily in Scotland with their baby son, Nabeel, who will celebrate his first birthday this week. However, many of his family and friends are still in Syria and he is worried about the impact of the pandemic there now.He is now speaking to the media to make an urgent call to the Scottish and British public to back the Disasters Emergency Committee appeal to help millions of people still caught up in the civil war in northwest Syria and now having to face the deadly threat of coronavirus without any adequate medical care.Dr Subeh said: ldquoThe health system in Syria cannot deal with this sort of pandemic, it is deprived of medical staffing, with numbers infected rising daily, doctors risk catching the virus and then passing it back to patients. Living in camps or in tents, it is really dficult to self-isolate, there arenrsquot enough intensive care beds, it is a really critical situation.Thanking people who have donated to the DEC appeal, he added: ldquoThinking outside your bubble during a pandemic, to not only help yourself but help others is very kind and generous. This is really important. Irsquom most certain this will help many, many people and it will save lives as well."@context": "https:schema.org","@type": "VideoObject","name": "syria","description": "syria","thumbnailUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer v media KbCxeqR poster.jpg width","uploadDate": "--T::+:","duration": "PDTHMS","contentUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer manests KbCxeqR.mu","embedUrl": "https:www.heraldscotland video  ","publisher": "@type": "Organization","name": "HeraldScotland","logo": "@type": "ImageObject","url": "https:www.heraldscotland sitelogo ","width": ,"height": But of his time working the pandemic frontline here in Scotland at Aberdeen Royal Infirmary, Dr Subeh, like many doctors he was understated.ldquoThe stress was everywhere at the beginning, less stressful than Syria but stressful in its own way. We were scared of getting the virus especially at first when I had to perform CPR on a patient without a full PPE mask, but it quickly got better. You just have to take a deep breath and try to work things through and it turned out well eventually.Syrian terrorSyria is in its th year of a civil war which has killed at least , civilians, , of them children. An estimated . million people need humanitarian assistance. The UN has called for an immediate countrywide ceasefire to allow an unrestricted response to the Covid- outbreak.The Syrian conflict triggered . million new displacements in , mostly the result of military offensives in the northeast and northwest of the country. Around . million people were living in internal displacement camps as of the end of that year. Many now live in tents in crowded camps on the border with Turkey with only basic facilities.Of the  public hospitals in Syria, only half are fully ing. There is a huge shortage with staff with % of health workers, like Dr Subeh, having already left the country.There are also shortages of ventilators, sterilisation equipment and personal protective equipment .Syria also faces a severe food crisis, partly as a result of the Covid- crisis. The World Food Programme says there is a risk of mass starvation in the country: ldquoWersquove got people on the brink of starvation now, and they canrsquot wait. People will die, and people are dying as we speak.The DEC AppealThe DEC appeal in Scotland has raised around pound. million in under two weeks as part of a UK wide total of more than poundm.The money raised is already being used by the DECrsquos member agencies to provide le-saving aid to millions of people in communities like those in northwest Syria and others where they now have to face the threat of coronavirus on top of existing extreme dangers of conflict, hunger and shortages of water to wash their hands to slow the spread of the virus.Sally Foster-Fulton, head of Christian Aid Scotland and the DEC Scotland chair, said: ldquoWe have seen here how deadly and frightening coronavirus can be. But just imagine what it would be like to be faced with the threat of Covid- when you live in an overcrowded refugee camp, where social distancing is impossible and where you donrsquot even have access to clean water to wash your hands.ldquoDuring the pandemic, communities across Scotland have come together to protect each other from the threat of the virus.ldquoNow wersquore asking people to show the same solidarity with people around the world facing this silent killer. While wersquore hugely grateful for all the generous support so far ndash more than one-and-a-half million donated in just over a week ndash we need a lot more.ldquoEvery pound counts and will help save lives.Funds raised by the appeal will go to help people in Yemen, Syria, Somalia, South Sudan, DRC, Afghanistan, and the Rohingya refugees in Bangladesh.Donations will be used to: provide families with clean water, soap and information on keeping themselves safe provide frontline medical and aid workers with equipment and supplies to care for the vulnerable and sick and ensure families get enough food to prevent malnutrition, particularly among children.The appeal has been backed by the Scottish Government, which has contributed pound, to the relief effort through its Humanitarian Emergency Fund.The appeal is also being supported by the UK Government through its Aid Match scheme.

title: snp-accused-inexcusable-money-making-branded-face-coverings
story: Despite Nicola Sturgeon accusing Boris Johnson of tasteless ldquocrowing about the Union during the crisis, her party is raising funds from face coverings costingup to pound each.The online store selling the partyrsquos official fundraising merchandise is currently selling a range of eight dferent face coverings.Three are in SNP yellow bearing the SNP logotwo are based on saltires with the SNP logo, one of which also uses the partyrsquos initials to spell out ldquoScottish N Proud two are in SNP tartan and one is in white with a multi-coloured Yes for independence logo.Five of the coverings are described as ldquoface masks made from ldquoa breathable polyester and cotton mix with ldquotwo replaceable carbon filters, and are priced at pound each.The website says: ldquoThe filters are shown to be effective in blocking the vast majority of airborne particles, however, this item is not classied as PPE Equipment.The otherthree coverings, priced at pound each, are described as ldquomulti-al headwear made from elastic breathable fabricthat ldquocan be worn in  dferent ways, including a balaclava, headband, bandana, neck warmer, and face mask.The store is owned and operated under licence by the Glasgow-based Business Incentives Group, which ldquospecialises in the sale and promotion of licensed merchandising.Scottish Conservative deputy leader Annie Wells said: ldquoThe decision by the SNP to try and make money from a global pandemic was inexcusable.ldquoNicola Sturgeon must immediately act to ensure this stops and is never repeated.ldquoAny money made from this tasteless venture should be donated to causes fighting coronavirus and its ruinous impact.An SNP spokesperson said: ldquoJust like football clubs and many others, wersquove launched our own branded face coverings. We would encourage everyone to help suppress the virus by following the guidance on face coverings.

title: four public toilet sites to reopen with more to follow
story: Public toilets at four more sites will reopen on Monday, July .These are at Finstown, Stenness, St Mary’s and Cromarty Square in St Margaret’s Hope, with more to follow over the weeks ahead.Earlier this month, Orkney Islands Council reopened toilets at the Travel Centre and St Magnus Lane in Kirkwall and at the Pier Head and Ferry Road in Stromness.“We are now working on the logistics of opening the toilets at our more remote and rural locations,” said Hayley Green, OIC’s Head of IT and Facilities.“The reason we cannot reopen all toilets at once is to ensure we comply with Government guidelines, which include having to introduce more frequent cleaning to reduce the risk of COVID- transmission to the public and to our staff.“We will publicise all re-openings as soon as we can confirm the dates.”If you find any problems with any of the opened toilets, please contact OIC Customer Services on , giving details of the issue and the location of the toilet.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co.
