They also said a trial period will not take place in August and September.Ideas, revealed by the town council in an online questionnaire on Friday, includes a pedestrianised ldquosafe space on Windsor Road from Arcot Street to the roundabout, including the bottom of Lower Glebe Street.Other plans for Windsor Road could include ldquoshared spaces between pedestrians and traffic during set times, while another included only allowing service traffic ndash such as delivery vehicles ndash to access Windsor Road and Lower Glebe Street.One of the major points for discussion is around proposals for a one-way traffic system incorporating Albert Road, Stanwell Road, Hickman Road, Arcot Street,Glebe Street and Ludlow Lane.The grey area marks the safe space pedestrianised proposal.The town council say the one-way system would enable more chevron parking on Plassey Street, Albert Road and Stanwell Road.Ceri McCann, Rachel Came and Karen Hatton at Andrearsquos Flower Boutique on Glebe Street, think the town will sufferpedestrianisation plans go ahead.: Karen Hatton, Ceri McCann and Rachel Came at Andreas Flower Boutique, Glebe Street" alt"Penarth Times: : Karen Hatton, Ceri McCann and Rachel Came at Andreas Flower Boutique, Glebe Street" class"editor-image": Karen Hatton, Ceri McCann and Rachel Came at Andreas Flower Boutique, Glebe StreetldquoPenarth isnrsquot the type of place you come to and spend a day, itrsquos a place people come and park up and quickly do some shopping, they said. ldquoBusinesses are already feeling the impact of lower footfall due to the social distancing parking trials, and to add this to the mix is poor timing.The plans also include additional bus stops, including one right outside Joan Painesrsquo funeral directors.The new ideas are designed to bring an additional  spaces to the town centre, but this is likely to affect residentsShe says buses stopping outside her shop every half an hour - combined with the one-way system - would be likely to cause too much congestion.ldquoMy main concern is the congestion and the impact that will have on my customers, she said. ldquoIt is not nice to have so much noise, fumes, and congestion outside when yoursquore trying to sort out a funeral.Joan and Tony Paines have made a blown up version of the main town area, so people can better understand the ideas.Ms Paines suggested a bus terminal at Station Approach, and said she thinks a one-way system around the town will also cause heavy traffic on smaller roads such as Railway Terrace, Grove Terrace and Woodland Place.Resident and member of Friendsof the Earth Barry andVale Max Wallis said he is in support of partial pedestrianisation, but questioned the one-way system idea.Mr Wallis said that a one-way system would ldquoworsen traffic and add to town centre pollution, adding: ldquoCovid- will force new thinking. People see the benefits of more walking and cycling. Some shops and businesses will close, with more online shopping. The town centre must become more a meeting and activity place access by bus or bike is more attractive withthe reduced traffic.       ,params: .pushMax WallisStrategic consultant John Jackson, who lives in Penarth, is in favour of partial pedestrianisation of Windsor Road on a trial basis.ldquoThis system works abroad, and works abroad in places where the weather isnrsquot always nice, he said. ldquoI think Penarth needs to be a more attractive environment post lockdown, and that would involve some sort of pedestrianisation.ldquoI think the idea to close off Windsor Road from Lower Glebe Street to the roundabout isnrsquot a bad one, and could instil some confidence for future changes.ldquoWhat I would question is whether the timing is right so soon after businesses have reopened.Five hundred people have responded to the town council survey so far.Cllr Nigel Humphrey - for St Augustines - said: ldquoPeople have been responding to the survey asit is a done deal, when in fact it is intended as part of a constructive dialogue about the future of our town centre."Gideon Calder of Gwyrddio Penarth Greeningsaid: ldquoFrom conversations with people, some are assuming that the current arrangement in the town centre ndash the bollards and one-way system ndash is the same thing as these alternative ideas about creating safer space."In fact these plans are quite dferent. Later, some onlookers sang the civil rights anthem We Shall Overcome and other gospel tunes.Mr Lewis died on July  at , months after he was diagnosed with advanced pancreatic cancer.Mr Lewis served in the US House of Representatives for Georgiarsquos th congressional district from  until his death.The wagon rolled over a carpet of rose petals, pausing on the bridge over the Alabama River in the summer heat so family members could walk behind it.On the south side of the bridge, where Mr Lewis was beaten by Alabama state troopers in , family members placed red roses that the carriage rolled over, marking the spot where Mr Lewis spilled his blood and suffered a head injury.As a military honour guard lted Mr Lewisrsquos coffin from the horse-drawn wagon into a hearse, Alabama state troopers, including some African American ones, saluted Mr Lewis.Franz and Ellen Hill drove more that four hours from Monroe, Louisiana, to watch the procession. vw,vw,px, px"Mourners watched the procession Franz Hill, , said he remembers, as an African American child, watching news footage of Mr Lewis and other civil rights marchers being beaten by law enforcement officers.ldquoI had to come back and see John Lewis cross the bridge for the last time, said Mr Hill.Mr Lewisrsquos body was then taken to the Alabama Capitol in the afternoon to lie in repose, retracing the route marchers took in the days after Bloody Sunday to demand justice from Alabama Governor George Wallace.Bertha Surles and Edna Goldsmith stood along the highway between Selma and Montgomery to pay their final respects. Both carried signs, reading ldquoThank you.ldquoHe fought for rights up unto his death, said Ms Surles, . vw,vw,px, px"The coffin was carried by horse-drawn carriage A series of events began on Saturday in Mr Lewisrsquos hometown of Troy, Alabama, to pay tribute the late congressman and his legacy. story: McConville wins legal battle for web accessTributes flood social media after tragic death of  year old manNewsTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthPeopleRead ThisCoronavirusSportFootballOther SportWhats OnArts and EntertainmentThings To DoLestyleCarsHomes and GardensNewsPoliticsCalls for Youth Council in ABC areaHopes are high that Armagh, Banbridge and Craigavon will launch a Youth Council after the NI Youth Assembly has been set up.By Carmel RobinsonThursday, rd July , : pm""Hopes are high that Armagh, Banbridge and Craigavon will launch a Youth Council after the NI Youth Assembly has been set up.Alliance Cllr Eóin Tennyson said he is delighted to see the NI Youth Assembly up and running, adding those involved must seize the opportunity to address issues important to them.It follows counterparts in England, Scotland and Wales setting up a similar assembly.Eóin added: “Being young should never be a barrier to politics and as a young Councillor myself, I only wish the Youth Assembly could have been in operation earlier – too many voices of the future could have slipped through the cracks and will be now never be heard.“And this has the added impact of our Councillors pushing ahead to help young people in the area and I’m hoping to see a Youth Council launched in my own council area for local engagement.“We must do all we can to encourage young people, our future leaders, to take an active interest in the world around this today. A youth Assembly is a fantastic setting to encourage debate and allow our young people to opportunity to hold their elected representatives to account. They must not be weary of pursuing their own agenda and really making their mark on the issues that matter to them.“Over the coming two year period the Alliance Party is looking forward to engaging further with the Youth Assembly and we hope to see an inclusive body, reflective of our society today.”A message from the Editor:Thank you for reading this story on our website.
